raw_text: To attempt to overcome this issue, both Passonneau and Litman (1993) and Hearst (1993) conflated multiple manual segmentations into one that contained only those boundaries which the majority of coders agreed upon
clean_text: To attempt to overcome this issue, both Passonneau and Litman (1993) and Hearst (1993) conflated multiple manual segmentations into one that contained only those boundaries which the majority of coders agreed upon.

raw_text: Additionally, the definition of what constitutes a majority is subjective (e.g., Passonneau and Litman (1993, p. 150), Litman and Passonneau (1995), Hearst (1993, p. 6) each used 4/7, 3/7, and& gt; 50%, respectively)
clean_text: Additionally, the definition of what constitutes a majority is subjective (e.g., Passonneau and Litman (1993, p. 150), Litman and Passonneau (1995), Hearst (1993, p. 6) each used 4/7, 3/7, and > 50%, respectively).

raw_text: Similar to (Passonneau and Litman, 1993), we adopt a flat model of topic segmentation for our gold standard based on discourse segment purpose, where a shift in topic corresponds to a shift in purpose that is acknowledged and acted upon by both conversational agents
